chapter.title: Type system
chapter.para: Every value in a Ceylon program is an instance of a type that can be expressed within the Ceylon language as a class. The language does not define any primitive or compound types that cannot, in principle, be expressed within the language itself.

A class is a recipe for producing new values, called instances of the class (or simply objects), and defines the operations and attributes of the resulting values. A class instance may hold references to other objects, and has an identity distinct from these references.

Each class declaration defines a type. However, not all types are classes. It is often advantageous to write generic code that abstracts the concrete class of a value. This technique is called polymorphism. Ceylon supports two different kinds of polymorphism:

listitem.para: subtype polymorphism, where a subtype B inherits a supertype A, and
parametric polymorphism, where a type definition A<T> is parameterized by a generic type parameter T.

chapter.para: Ceylon, like Java and many other object-oriented languages, supports a single inheritance model for classes. A class may directly inherit at most one other class, and all classes eventually inherit, directly or indirectly, the class Void defined in the module ceylon.language, which acts as the root of the class hierarchy.
A truly hierarchical type system is much too restrictive for more abstract programming tasks. Therefore, in addition to classes, Ceylon recognizes the following kinds of type:

listitem.para: An interface is an abstract type schema that cannot itself be directly instantiated. An interface may define concrete members, but these members may not hold references to other objects. A class may inherit one or more interfaces. An instance of a class that inherits an interface is also considered an instance of the interface.

A generic type parameter is considered a type within the declaration that it parameterizes. In fact, it is an abstraction over many types: it generalizes the declaration to all types which could be assigned to the parameter.
A produced type is formed by specifying arguments for the generic type parameters of a parameterized type.
A union type is a type to which each of an enumerated list of produced types is assignable.
An intersection type is a type which is assignable to each of an enumerated list of produced types.

chapter.para: Although we often use the term parameterized type or even generic type to refer to a parameterized type definition, it is important to keep in mind that a parameterized type definition is not itself a type. Rather, it is a type constructor, a function that maps types to types. Given a list of type arguments, the function yields a produced type.

The Ceylon type system is much more complete than most other object oriented languages. In Ceylon, it's possible to answer questions that might at first sound almost nonsensical if you're used to languages with more traditional type systems. For example:

listitem.para: What is the return type of a void method?
What is the type of an local that may or may not hold a value of type Element?
What is the type of a parameter that accepts either a String or a sequence of Strings?
What is the type of a parameter that accepts values which are instances of both Persistent and Printable?
What is the type of a nonempty sequence of Integers, Floats, and Strings?
What is the type that represents methods that accept two Float values?
What is the type that represents subclasses of Renderer which must be provided at instantiation time with a function that accepts an object and produces a String?

chapter.para: The answers, as we shall discover, are: Void, Nothing|Element, String|String[], Persistent&Printable, Method<Object,Void,Float,Float>, Sequence<Integer|Float|String> and Class<Renderer,Callable<String,Object>>.

It's important that there is always a unique "best" answer to questions like this in Ceylon. The "best" answer is called the principal type of an expression. Every other type to which the expression is assignable is a supertype of the principal type.

Thus, every legal Ceylon expression has a unique, computable, well-defined type without reference to how the expression is used or to what type it is assigned. This is the case even when type inference or type argument inference is used.

Neither this specification nor the internal implementation of the Ceylon compiler itself use any kind of "non-denotable" types. Every type mentioned here or inferred internally by the compiler has a representation within the language itself. Thus, the programmer is never exposed to confusing error messages referring to mysterious types that are not part of the syntax of the language.

The ability to represent types like Method, Class, and Callable within the type system, and to therefore write code that operates on instances of these types in a typesafe way is what makes Ceylon a higher order language.

section.title: Identifier naming
section.para: The Ceylon compiler enforces identifier naming conventions. Types must be named with an initial uppercase. Members, parameters and locals must be named with an initial lowercase or underscore. A package name element is an all-lowercase identifier.
An underscore _ is considered a lowercase letter.
Ceylon defines three identifier namespaces:

listitem.para: classes, interfaces, and type parameters share a single namespace,
methods, attributes, and locals share a single namespace, and
packages have their own dedicated namespace.

section.para: The Ceylon parser is able to unambiguously identify which namespace an identifier belongs to.

section.title: Types
section.para: A type or type schema is a name (an initial uppercase identifier) and an optional list of type parameters, with a set of:

listitem.para: attribute schemas,
method schemas, and
class schemas.

section.para: The attribute, method, and class schemas are called the members of the type.
Speaking formally:

listitem.para: An attribute schema is a name (an initial lowercase identifier) with a type and mutability.
A method schema is a name (an initial lowercase identifier) and an optional list of type parameters, with a type (often called the return type) and a list of one or more parameter lists.
A class schema is a type schema with a parameter list.
A parameter list is a list of names (initial lowercase identifiers) with types. The signature of a parameter list is formed by discarding the names, leaving the list of types.

section.para: Speaking slightly less formally, we usually refer to an attribute, method, or member class of a type, meaning an attribute schema, method schema or class schema that is a member of the type.

section.title: Member distinctness
section.para: Overloading is illegal in Ceylon. A type may not have:

listitem.para: two attributes with the same name,
a method and an attribute with the same name,
two methods with the same name, or
two member classes with the same name.

section.title: Subtyping
section.para: A type may be a subtype of another type. Subtyping obeys the following rules:

listitem.para: Identity: X is a subtype of X.
Transitivity: if X is a subtype of Y and Y is a subtype of Z then X is a subtype of Z.
Noncircularity: if X is a subtype of Y and Y is a subtype of X then Y and X are the same type.
Single root: all types are subtypes of the class Void defined in the module ceylon.language.

section.para: Every interface type is a subtype of the class Object defined in ceylon.language.
If X is a subtype of Y, then:

listitem.para: For each non-variable attribute of Y, X has an attribute with the same name, whose type is assignable to the type of the attribute of Y.
For each variable attribute of Y, X has a variable attribute with the same name and the same type.
For each method of Y, X has a method with the same name, with the same number of parameter lists, with the same signatures, and whose return type is assignable to the return type of the method of Y.
For each member class of Y, X has a member class of the same name, with a parameter list with the same signature, that is a subtype of the member class of Y.

section.para: Furthermore, we say that X is assignable to Y.

section.title: Union types
section.para: For any types X and Y, the union, or disjunction, X|Y, of the types may be formed. A union type is a supertype of both of the given types X and Y, and an instance of either type is an instance of the union type.
The union type constructor | is associative, so the union of three types may be written X|Y|Z.
If X and Y are both subtypes of a third type Z, then X|Y inherits all members of Z.
Union types satisfy the following rules, for any types X, Y, and Z:

listitem.para: Commutativity: X|Y is the same type as Y|X.
Associativity: X|(Y|Z) is the same type as (X|Y)|Z.
Simplification: if X is a subtype of Y, then X|Y is the same type as Y.
Subtypes: X is a subtype of X|Y.
Supertypes: if both X and Y are subtypes of Z, then X|Y is also a subtype of Z.

section.para: The following results follow from these rules:

listitem.para: X|Bottom is the same type as X for any type X, and
X|Void is the same type as Void for any type X.

section.para: Finally:

listitem.para: If X<T> is covariant in the type parameter T, then X<U>|X<V> is a subtype of X<U|V> for any types U and V that satisfy the type constraints on T.
If X<T> is contravariant in the type parameter T, then X<U>|X<V> is a subtype of X<U&V> for any types U and V that satisfy the type constraints on T.

section.title: Intersection types
section.para: For any types X and Y, the intersection, or conjunction, X&Y, of the types may be formed. An intersection type is a subtype of both of the given types X and Y, and any object which is an instance of both types is an instance of the union type.
The union type constructor & is associative, so the union of three types may be written X&Y&Z.
The intersection X&Y inherits all members of both X and Y.
Intersection types satisfy the following rules, for any types X, Y, and Z:

listitem.para: Commutativity: X&Y is the same type as Y&X.
Associativity: X&(Y&Z) is the same type as (X&Y)&Z.
Simplification: if X is a subtype of Y, then X&Y is the same type as X.
Supertypes: X is a supertype of X&Y.
Subtypes: if both X and Y are supertypes of Z, then X&Y is also a supertype of Z.
Distributivity over union: X&(Y|Z) is the same type as (X&Y)|(X&Z).

section.para: The following results follow from these rules:

listitem.para: X&Bottom is the same type as Bottom for any type X, and
X&Void is the same type as X for any type X.

section.para: Finally:

listitem.para: If X<T> is covariant in the type parameter T, then X<U>&X<V> is a supertype of X<U&V> for any types U and V that satisfy the type constraints on T.
If X<T> is contravariant in the type parameter T, then X<U>&X<V> is a supertype of X<U|V> for any types U and V that satisfy the type constraints on T.

section.title: The bottom type
section.para: The special type Bottom represents:

listitem.para: the intersection of all types, or, equivalently
the empty set.

section.para: Bottom is assignable to all other types, but has no instances.
A reference to a member of an expression of type Bottom is always an error, since there can never be a receiving instance.
Bottom is considered to belong to the module ceylon.language. However, its definition is actually implemented directly in the compiler.
Because of the restrictions imposed by Ceylon's mixin inheritance model:

listitem.para: If X and Y are classes, and X is not a subclass of Y, and Y is not a subclass of X, then the intersection type X&Y is equivalent to Bottom.
If X is an interface, the intersection type X&Nothing is equivalent to Bottom.

comment.para: TODO: Should the name of this type be a keyword, perhaps bottom?

section.title: Type of a program element
section.para: Method, attribute, and parameter declarations usually declare a type. Types are identified by the name of the type (a class, interface, or type parameter), together with a list of type arguments if the type definition specifies type parameters.
If the type is a class or interface nested inside a containing class or interface, the type must be fully qualified by its containing types, except when used inside the body of a containing type.

If a type has type parameters or a sequenced type parameter, a type argument list must be specified. If a type has no type parameters, and no sequenced type parameter, no type argument list may be specified.
The name of a type may not be qualified by the package name.

comment.para: TODO: Should we introduce a special syntax for qualification of identifiers by package name, for example, :ceylon:language:metamodel:Class? This would also allow us to have metamodel references for packages. Using . as a qualifier is not an option, since it would make the grammar context-senstive like in Java.

section.title: Type inference
section.para: Certain declarations which usually require an explicit type may omit the type, forcing the compiler to infer it, by specifying the keyword value or function where the type usually appears.

Type inference is only allowed for block local declarations. The keywords value and function may not be combined with the shared annotation. Nor may they may they be used to declare a toplevel method or attribute.

Type inference is supported for declarations which are are referred to only by statements and declarations that occur within the lexical scope of the declaration. Type inference is not supported for shared declarations which may be accessed from outside the body containing the declaration, or for declarations which are referred to by statements or declarations that occur earlier in the body containing of the declaration.

section.title: Type name abbreviations
section.para: Certain important types may be written using an abbreviated syntax.

listitem.para: X? means Nothing|X for any type X,
X[] means Empty|Sequence<X> for any type X,
X->Y means Entry<X,Y>, and
X(Y,Z) means Callable<X,Y,Z> where Y, Z is a list of types of any length.

section.para: Abbreviations may be combined:
When a type appears in an expression, the abbreviations cannot be used (they cannot be disambiguated from operator expressions).

comment.para: TODO: Java lets you put the [] after the variable name. C requires that. Should we support/require this variation? It is consistent with how we declare functional parameters!

section.title: Inheritance
section.para: Subtyping is a static relationship between classes, interfaces, and type parameters, produced through the use of inheritance:

listitem.para: a class may extend another class,
a class may satisfy one or more interfaces,
an interface may satisfy one or more other interfaces,
a type parameter may satisfy a class and/or one or more interfaces or type parameters, or
a type parameter may abstract a class, interface or type parameter.

section.para: If a type declaration extends or satisfies a type, we say it inherits the type. Inheritance results in a relationship called invariant subtyping between produced types.

listitem.para: If a type X inherits a type Y, then X is an invariant subtype of Y.
If a parameterized type X<T> inherits a type Y, then the produced type X<B> is an invariant subtype of Y for any type B.

If a parameterized type X<T> inherits a produced type Y<T> that depends upon the type parameter T, then the produced type X<B> is an invariant subtype of the produced type Y<B> formed by substituting B for T for any type B.

section.para: If a type is an invariant subtype of a second type then it is a subtype of the second type.

comment.para: TODO: these rules need to be formalized into the language of type constructors (functions from types to types).

section.para: Ceylon visually distinguishes between a list of types which represents a combination (intersection) of the types, and a list of types which represents a choice between (union of) the types. An intersection is written as X & Y & Z. A union is written as X | Y | Z.

section.title: Principal instantiation inheritance
section.para: If a class or interface A is a subtype of the types B<X> and B<Y> for some parameterized type B<T>, and types X and Y, then A must also be a subtype of B<Z> for some subtype Z of X and Y.
Or, equivalently, B<T> must not be invariant in T and A must also be a subtype of:

listitem.para: B<X&Y> if B<T> is covariant in T, or
B<X|Y> if B<T> is contravariant in T.

section.para: It further follows that if X and Y are distinct types, and B<T> is invariant in T, then the type B<X>&B<Y> is the empty type Bottom.

section.title: Extension
section.para: A class may extend another class, in which case the first class is a subtype of the second class and inherits its members.

The extends clause must specify exactly one superclass. If the superclass is a parameterized type, the extends clause must specify type arguments. The extends clause must specify arguments for the initializer parameters of the superclass.

A member class annotated actual may use the qualifier super in the extends clause to refer to the member class it refines. When the qualifier super appears, the following class name refers to a member class of the superclass of the class that contains the member class annotated actual.

comment.para: TODO: This doesn't work if the member class being refined belongs to an interface. A solution would be to let you rename the refined member class in an import statement. Another possibility would be to introduce a specialized syntax, for example something like super(Reader).Buffer().

section.para: The root class Void defined in ceylon.language does not have a superclass.

section.title: Satisfaction
section.para: The satisfies clause does double duty. It's used to specify that a type is a subtype of an interface, and to specify upper bound type constraints.

listitem.para: A class or interface may satisfy one or more interfaces, in which case the class or interface is a subtype of the satisfied interfaces, and inherits their members.

A type parameter may satisfy one or more interfaces, optionally, a class, and optionally, another type parameter. In this case, the satisfied types are interpreted as upper bound type constraints on arguments to the type parameter.

section.para: The satisfies clause may specify multiple types. If a satisfied type is a parameterized type, the satisfies clause must specify type arguments.

section.title: Cases
section.para: The of clause does triple duty. It's used to define self types and type families, algebraic types, and enumerated type constraints.

listitem.para: An interface or abstract class may optionally specify an enumerated list of all its subtypes, in which case no other type may be a direct subtype of the interface or abstract class.
Likewise, a type parameter may specify an enumerated list of all types which it accepts as a type argument.
An interface or abstract class may specify a single type parameter of itself or of the immediately containing type.

section.para: A type declaration with an of clause is called an enumerated type.
The of clause may specify multiple types, called cases.
The compiler is able to infer certain subtyping relationships from the types listed in the of clause.

listitem.para: If every case of a type X is an invariant suptype of a type Y, then X is an invariant subtype of Y.
If every case of a parameterized type X<T> is an invariant suptype of a type Y, then the produced type X<B> is an invariant subtype of Y for any type B.

If every case of a parameterized type X<T> is an invariant suptype of a produced type Y<T> that depends upon the type parameter T, then the produced type X<B> is an invariant subtype of the produced type Y<B> formed by substituting B for T for any type B.

section.para: If there is exactly one case, and it is a type parameter, then:

listitem.para: the declared type is considered a subtype of the type parameter within the body of the declaration,
every produced type of the declared type is considered a subtype of the type argument to the type parameter in the produced type, and
every type which extends or satisfies a produced type of the declared type must also directly or indirectly extend or satisfy the type argument to the type parameter in the produced type.

section.para: Otherwise, there may be multiple cases, and each case is either:

listitem.para: a subtype of the interface or abstract class, or
the name specified in the object declaration of a toplevel anonymous class that is a subtype of the interface or abstract class.

section.para: An explicit list of cases allows safe use of a type in a switch statement. The compiler is able to validate that the switch contains an exhaustive list of all cases of the type.

comment.para: TODO: If all cases of an interface or class are subtypes of a certain type, does the compiler automatically reason that the interface or class is a subtype of that type?

section.para: Therefore, the of declaration is used to simulate enumerated types and algebraic types.
A class or interface may not be a subtype of more than one case of an enumerated type.

section.title: PROPOSAL: Generalized algebraic types

comment.para: NOTE: Generalized algebraic types are a proposed feature for a future version of the language.

listitem.para: A simple algebraic datatype is a parameterized type A<T> with a list of cases where every case C<T> is parameterized by T and for every possible type argument X satisfying the constraints on T declared by A, C<X> is a legal produced type where X also satisfies the constraints on T declared by C and the produced type C<X> is assignable to the produced type A<X>.

A generalized algebraic datatype is a parameterized type A<T> with a list of cases where either (a) at least one case is not parameterized by T—and is therefore assignable to A<Y> only for some values of the type argument Y, or (b) for at least one case C<X> there is a type argument X satisfying the constraints on T declared by A where C<X> is not a legal produced type since X does not satisfy a constraint on T declared by C.

section.para: Given a parameterized type A<T>, a case C<T> of A<T>, and a type argument X of T, we say that C<X> is the produced case of the produced type A<X>.

The cases of a produced type A<X> for a simple algebraic datatype A<T> and a type argument X include exactly every produced case C<X> for a case C<T> of A<T>. Therefore, for every case of the simple algebraic datatype A<T>, there is a corresponding produced case of A<X>.
On the other hand, the cases of a produced type A<X> for a generalized algebraic datatype A<T> and a type argument X include only the following:

listitem.para: every case C of A<T> which is not parameterized by T and which is assignable to A<X>, and
every produced case C<X> for a case C<T> of A<T> which is a legal produced type where X satisfies all constraints on T declared by C.

section.para: Therefore, for a given case of the generalized algebraic datatype A<T>, there may be no corresponding case of A<X>. In the extreme case that there is exactly one case of the produced type A<X>, the compiler treats the type A<X> as a type alias of that unique case. Hence, A<X> may have members that are not part of the parameterized type schema A<T>.

Then the type Expression<String> has the attributes uppercase and lowercase, even though the parameterized type Expression<Value> does not declare these members.

section.title: PROPOSAL: Introduction

comment.para: NOTE: Introductions are a proposed feature for a future version of the language.

section.para: A toplevel interface may adapt a list of types, in which case it is called an introduction. The types are called adapted types.
The adapts clause may specify multiple types. If a satisfied type is a parameterized type, the satisfies clause must specify type arguments.
Each adapted type must be class or interface. At most one adapted type may be a class.
An introduction introduces new types to every type that is a subtype of all the adapted types in:

listitem.para: any compilation unit that imports the introduction, and
the package to which the introduction belongs.

section.para: Specifically:

listitem.para: If a type X adapts a type Y, then Y is an invariant subtype of X in every compilation unit that imports X and in the package to which X belongs.
If a parameterized type X<T> inherits a type Y, then Y is an invariant subtype of the produced type X<B> for any type B in every compilation unit that imports X and in the package to which X belongs.

If a parameterized type X<T> inherits a produced type Y<T> that depends upon the type parameter T, then the produced type Y<B> formed by substituting B for T is an invariant subtype of the produced type X<B> for any type B in every compilation unit that imports X and in the package to which X belongs.

section.para: An introduction may not:

listitem.para: declare or inherit a member that refines a member of any adapted type, or
declare or inherit a formal or non-default actual member unless the member is inherited from an adapted type.

section.para: If, in a certain compilation unit, multiple introductions of a certain adapted type declare or inherit a member that refines a common member of a common supertype then either:

listitem.para: there must be a unique member from the set of members, called the most refined member, that refines all the other members, or
the adapted type must declare or inherit a member that refines all the members.

section.para: At runtime, an operation (method invocation, member class instantiation, or attribute evaluation) upon any type that is a subtype of all the adapted types is dispatched according to the following rule:

listitem.para: If the runtime type of the instance of the adapted type declares or inherits a member defining the operation, the operation is dispatched to the runtime type of the instance.
Otherwise, the operation is dispatched to the introduction that has the most-refined member defining the operation.

section.title: PROPOSAL: Metatypes

comment.para: NOTE: Metatypes are a proposed feature for a future version of the language.

section.para: Metatype inheritance operates at the level of the metamodel.

listitem.para: The concrete metatype of a type T is the concrete class of the object to which the expression T evaluates. The name of this class is not specified here. A class or interface may optionally specify a list of additional metatypes, interfaces satisfied by the concrete metatype of the type. A metatype may not declare or inherit a formal member.
A type constraint may specify a list of metatype bounds which must be satisfied by the concrete metatype of the type argument.

A class or method declaration may explicitly specify a declared callable type satisfied by the callable type of the class or method. The declared callable type must by a produced type for the parameterized type Callable.

section.para: The is clause may specify multiple types, all of which must be interfaces.

section.title: Generic type parameters
section.para: Methods, class, and interface declarations may be parameterized by one or more generic type parameters. A parameterized class or interface declaration defines a type constructor, a function that produces a type given a tuple of compatible type arguments. A parameterized class or method declaration defines a function that produces the signature of an invokable operation given a tuple of compatible type arguments.
A declaration with type parameters is called generic or parameterized.

listitem.para: A type declaration with no type parameters defines exactly one type. A parameterized type declaration defines a template for producing types: one type for each possible combination of type arguments that satisfy the type constraints specified by the type. The types of members of the this type are determined by replacing every appearance of each type parameter in the schema of the parameterized type definition with its type argument.

A method declaration with no type parameters defines exactly one operation per type. A parameterized method declaration defines a template for producing overloaded operations: one operation for each possible combination of type arguments that satisfy the type constraints specified by the method declaration.

A class declaration with no type parameters defines exactly one instantiation operation. A parameterized class declaration defines a template for producing overloaded instantiation operations: one instantiation operation for each possible combination of type arguments that satisfy the type constraints specified by the class declaration. The type of the object produced by an instantiation operation is determined by substituting the same combination of type arguments for the type parameters of the parameterized class.

comment.para: Note: by convention, type parameter names should be constructed from meaningful words. The use of single-letter type parameter names is discouraged. The name of a type parameter should be chosen so that declarations within the body of the parameterized declaration read naturally. For example, class Entry<Key,Item> is reasonable, since Key key and Item item read naturally within the body of the Entry class. The following identifier names usually refer to a type parameter: Element, Other, Key, Item, Argument and Result. Avoid, where reasonable, using these names for interfaces and classes.

section.title: Type parameters and variance
section.para: An ordinary type parameter allows a declaration to be abstracted over a constrained set of types.
Every ordinary type parameter has a name. A parameter of a class or interface declaration has a specified variance.

listitem.para: A covariant type parameter is indicated using the keyword out.
A contravariant type parameter is indicated using the keyword in.
By default, a type parameter is invariant.

section.para: An ordinary type parameter of a method declaration may not specify an explicit variance and, for the purposes of this section, are considered invariant

Within the body of the declaration it parameterizes, an ordinary type parameter is itself a type. The type parameter is a subtype of every upper bound of the type parameter. However, a class or interface may not extend or satisfy a type parameter.
section.programlisting: BinaryFunction<in Left, in Right, out Result>
section.para: A covariant type parameter may only appear in covariant positions of the parameterized declaration. A contravariant type parameter may only appear in contravariant positions of the parameterized declaration. Invariant type parameters may appear in any position. As a special exception to this rule, any type parameter or a method or class may appear in any position in the parameter list of the method or class itself.
Furthermore, a type with a contravariant type parameter may only appear in a covariant position in an extended type, satisfied type, case type, or upper bound type constraint.

comment.para: Note: this restriction exists to eliminate certain undecidable cases described in Tate et al.

section.para: To determine if a type expression occurs in a covariant or contravariant position, we first consider how the type occurs syntactically.
In a method declaration:

listitem.para: The return type of the method is a covariant position.
A parameter type of the method is a contravariant position.
Any upper bound of a type parameter of the method is a contravariant position.
Any lower bound of a type parameter of the method is a covariant position.

section.para: In a simple attribute declaration not annotated variable, or an attribute getter declaration with no matching setter:

listitem.para: The type of the attribute is a covariant position.

section.para: In a simple attribute declaration annotated variable, or an attribute getter declaration with a matching setter:

listitem.para: The type of the attribute is an invariant position.

section.para: In a class declaration:

listitem.para: An initializer parameter type of the class is a contravariant position.
Any upper bound of a type parameter of the class is a contravariant position.
Any lower bound of a type parameter of the class is a covariant position.
An extended type, satisfied type, or case type is a covariant position.

section.para: In an interface declaration:

listitem.para: An extended type, satisfied type, or case type is a covariant position.

section.para: For parameters of callable parameters, we first determine if the callable parameter itself is covariant or contravariant:

listitem.para: A callable parameter of a method or class is contravariant.
A callable parameter of a covariant parameter is contravariant.
A callable parameter of a contravariant parameter is covariant.

section.para: Then:

listitem.para: The return type of a covariant callable parameter is a covariant position.
The return type of a contravariant callable parameter is a contravariant position.
The type of a parameter of a covariant callable parameter is a contravariant position.
The type of a parameter of a contravariant callable parameter is a covariant position.

section.para: Finally, to determine if a type parameter that occurs as a type argument occurs in a covariant or contravariant position, we must consider the declared variance of the corresponding type parameter:

listitem.para: A type argument of a covariant type parameter of a type in a covariant position is a covariant position.
A type argument of a contravariant type parameter of a type in a covariant position is a contravariant position.
A type argument of a covariant type parameter of a type in a contravariant position is a contravariant position.
A type argument of a contravariant type parameter of a type in a contravariant position is a covariant position.
A type argument of an invariant type parameter of a type in any position is an invariant position.
A type argument of any type parameter of a type in an invariant position is an invariant position.

section.title: Type parameters and enumerated types
section.para: If an enumerated type T<X> has a case type which is a produced type of U then either:

listitem.para: U is parameterized by a type parameter X and U<X> is an invariant subtype of T<X>,
T<X> is covariant in X and U is an invariant subtype of T<Bottom>, or
T<X> is contravariant in X and U is an invariant subtype of T<Void>. (TODO: should be the intersection of upper bounds.)

section.para: If U<X> is a case of an enumerated type T<X>, then U<X> must be an invariant subtype of T<X> and:

listitem.para: if T<X> is covariant in X then U<Y> must be covariant in Y, and
if T<X> is contravariant in X then U<Y> must be contravariant in Y.

section.title: Sequenced type parameters
section.para: A sequenced type parameter allows a declaration to be abstracted over a variable length list of arbitrary types. This allows declarations with parameter lists to be represented by metamodel objects within the language.
A sequenced type parameter is identified by an elipsis ..., indicating that it accepts a list of zero or more type arguments.
Sequenced type parameters are always non-variant.

Inside the declaration of the parameterized type or method, a sequenced type parameter may be used as a type argument to other types which accept a sequenced type parameter, or it may be used as the type of the last parameter declared by a parameter list. It may not appear in any other position. The sequenced type parameter acts as a pseudo-type. It is treated by the Ceylon compiler as if it were a type with no members, to which no other type may be assigned, and which can only by assigned to itself.

comment.para: TODO: Should we let you declare a covariant sequenced type parameter? This is useful for modelling tuples. Should we allow you to declare a contravariant sequenced type parameter, and say that method parameter types are contravariant?

section.title: PROPOSAL: Parameterized type parameters

comment.para: NOTE: Parameterized type parameters is a proposed feature for a future version of the language.

section.para: A parameterized type parameter is defined using a type constraint of form given X<T>, which specifies that the type parameter is itself a parameterized type.
The parameters of a parameterized type parameter may themselves have constraints. These constraints are be defined in the same list of type constraints.
A type argument to a parameterized type parameter must be a parameterized type with type parameters to which the type parameters of the parameterized type parameter are assignable.
A parameterized type parameter appears as a produced type (with type arguments) in the body of the declaration.

Note that the argument to a parameterized type parameter is not, strictly speaking, a type. Rather, it is a parameterized type—a type constructor. For example, in the following, WeakReference is viewed as a function from types Anything to produced types WeakReference<Anything>:
Parameterized type parameters allow functions to operate generically over "container" types:
section.programlisting: Set<Person> people = ... ; Set<String> names = map(Person.name, people);
section.para: This effect can not even be achieved with metatypes. Even some cases which can be expressed using metatypes are more elegantly expressed using parameterized type parameters:

comment.para: Note: I think you can get most of the practical value by limiting type constructor parameterization to methods only. Supporting type constructor parameterization of classes and interfaces means that you have to be able to reason about types whose arguments are type constructors. It seems to me that you don't need to be able to do this if the feature is limited to methods. On the other hand, regularity argues for supporting both.
TODO: There are at least two other interesting functions which map types to types:

listitem.para: the identity type constructor id<T> == T, and
constant type constructors (non-parameterized types), for example, String<T> == String.

comment.para: Should we allow these type constructors as arguments to a parameterized type parameter?
Note that given S<X> satisfies Sequence<X> | X is a way of writing given S<X> satisfies Sequence<X> | id<X>. A second example:
comment.programlisting: Result[] findManyByIntegerKey<Result>(Type<Result> type, Integer[] keys) = findByKey<Sequence,Result,Integer>; Result findSingleByIntegerKey<Result>(Type<Result> type, Integer key) = findByKey<id,Result,Integer>;
comment.para: Or we could keep it simple :-)

section.title: Generic type constraints
section.para: A parameterized method, class, or interface declaration may declare constraints upon ordinary type parameters using the given clause.
There may be at most one given clause per type parameter.
Note that the syntax for a type constraint is essentially the same syntax used for other type declarations such as class and interface declarations.
There are five different kinds of type constraint:

listitem.para: an upper bound, given X satisfies T, specifies that the type parameter X is a subtype of a given type T,
a lower bound, given X abstracts T, specifies that a given type T is a subtype of the type parameter X,
an enumerated bound, given X of T|U|V specifies that the type parameter X represents one of the enumerated types,
a parameter bound, given X(...) specifies that the type parameter X is a concrete class with the given parameter types, and

a metatype bound, given X is T, specifies that the concrete metatype of the type parameter is a subtype of a given type T. (Note that metatypes are a proposed feature for a future version of the language.)

section.para: A constraint may not refer to a sequenced type parameter.

A single given clause may specify multiple constraints on a certain type parameter. For example, it may specify multiple upper bounds together with a parameter bound. If multiple upper bounds are specified, at most one upper bound may be a class.
section.programlisting: given Value(Integer n) satisfies IdentifiableObject & Comparable<Value>
given Value satisfies Numberic<Value> given Result(Integer count) satisfies Numeric<Result>
given Other satisfies Ordinal & Comparable<Other> abstracts Element
given Argument of String | Integer | Float

comment.para: TODO: Should we let you declare a constraint for a sequenced type parameter?
TODO: Should we inherit generic type constraints from supertypes, like in C#, or require them to be re-declared, like in Java?

section.title: Upper bounds
section.para: An upper bound constraint makes the type parameter assignable to the upper bound type, and allows operations of the upper bound type to be called upon expressions whose type is the type parameter.
Every type parameter has an implicit upper bound of type Void.

section.title: Lower bounds
section.para: A lower bound constraint makes the lower bound type assignable to the type parameter. The most common usecase is to work around the restriction that a covariant type parameter may not appear in a contravariant position of the schema of the parameterized type.

A type parameter of a declaration may not appear anywhere in any lower bound constraint on any type parameter of the same declaration. It may appear in any constraint on any type parameter of a nested declaration.

section.title: Enumerated bounds
section.para: An enumerated bound allows the use of an exhaustive switch with expressions of the parameter type.

section.title: Parameter bounds
section.para: A parameter bound allows instantiation of the type represented by the type parameter within the body of the declaration.

section.title: PROPOSAL: Metatype bounds

comment.para: NOTE: Metatypes are a proposed feature for a future version of the language.

is equivalent to a metatype bound of this form:
and that a parameter bound type constraint of form:

section.title: Generic type constraints and assignability
section.para: Within the body of the declaration, a generic type constraint affects the assignability of a type parameter:

listitem.para: A type parameter is considered a subtype of its upper bound.
The lower bound of a type parameter is considered a subtype of the type parameter.
A metamodel reference to the type parameter is assignable to the metatype bound.
A type parameter is considered a supertype of its enumerated type bounds.

section.title: Generic type arguments
section.para: A list of type arguments produces a new type schema from a parameterized type schema, or a new method schema from a method schema with type parameters.
A type argument list is a list of types and dimensions, and an optional sequenced type argument.
A sequenced type argument is either:

listitem.para: a reference to a sequenced type parameter of the containing declaration, or
a sequenced type, which represents a sequence of values of some specified type.

section.para: A sequenced type argument must appear last in the list of type arguments.
A type argument may itself be a parameterized type or type parameter.

section.title: Type arguments and type constraints
section.para: A generic type constraint affects the type arguments that can be assigned to a type parameter:

listitem.para: A type argument to a type parameter with an upper bound must be a type which is a subtype of all upper bounds.
A type argument to a type parameter with a lower bound must be a type of which all lower bounds are subtypes.

A type argument to a type parameter with an enumerated type bound must be a subtype of one of the enumerated types, or a type with an enumerated subtype list that is a subset of the enumerated types of the constraint.
A type argument to a type parameter with an initialization parameter specification must be a class with the given initialization parameter types.

A type argument to a type parameter with a metatype bound must have a metatype assignable to all metatype bounds. (Note that metatype bounds are a proposed feature for a future version of the language.)

section.title: Type argument conformance
section.para: A type argument list conforms to a type parameter list if:

listitem.para: a type argument that satisfies the constraints of the type parameter is specified for every ordinary type parameter,
if the type parameter list has no sequenced type parameter, then there are no additional type arguments, and no sequenced type argument.

section.title: Produced types and and variance
section.para: If a type argument list conforms to a type parameter list, the combination of the parameterized type together with the type argument list is itself a type, called a produced type.
For a generic type T<X>, the types T<A> and T<B> represent the same type if and only if A and B are the same type.
For a generic type T<X>, a type A, and a subtype B of A:

listitem.para: If X is a covariant type parameter, T<B> is a subtype of T<A>.
If X is a contravariant type parameter, T<A> is a subtype of T<B>.
If X is invariant (neither covariant nor contravariant), there is no subtype relationship between T<A> and T<B> unless A and B are the same type.

comment.para: Note that if X is an invariant type parameter, then a produced type S is a subtype of T<A> if and only if S is an invariant subtype of T<A>.

section.para: A produced type is a subtype of the type argument to any type parameter that appears in the of clause of the type declaration. If X is a type parameter of the parameterized type T<X> of X, then T<A> is assignable to A for every type argument A which satisfies the other type constraints on X.

section.title: Qualified types
section.para: If a class or interface declaration X<P1,P2,...> with type parameters P1,P2,... has a member class or interface declaration M<Q1,Q2,...>, then:

listitem.para: U.M<A1,A2,...> is a subtype of V.M<B1,B2,...> if U is a subtype of X<C1,C2,...> and V is an invariant subtype of X<C1,C2,...> and V directly inherits M from X without refining M and if M<A1,A2,...> is a subtype of M<B1,B2,...>.

M<A1,A2,...> is a subtype of V.M<B1,B2,...> if U is a subtype of X<C1,C2,...>and V is an invariant subtype of X<P1,P2,...> and V directly inherits M from X without refining M and if M<A1,A2,...> is a subtype of M<B1,B2,...>.

comment.para: Note that a type like M<A1,A2,...> is only well-formed inside the scope in which M is declared or imported. Outside this scope, references to M must be qualified by the containing type.

section.title: Type argument substitution
section.para: A type argument is substituted for every appearance of the corresponding type parameter in the schema of the parameterized declaration, including:

listitem.para: attribute types,
method return types,
method parameter types,
initializer parameter types, and
type arguments of extended classes and satisfied interfaces.

section.para: In the case of a sequenced type parameter:

listitem.para: the type arguments are appended to the list of type arguments in every parameterized type in which the sequenced type parameter appears, and
a list of parameters whose types are the type arguments is appended to the list of parameters of every parameter list in which the sequenced type parameter appears.

section.para: A sequenced type in a type argument list results in a sequenced parameter in a parameter list.
A reference to a sequenced type parameter in a type argument list results in a tuple parameter in a parameter list.

section.title: Reification
section.para: Type arguments are reified in Ceylon. An instance of a generic type holds a reference to its type arguments. Therefore, the following are legal in Ceylon:

listitem.para: testing the runtime value of a type argument of an instance, for example, objectList is List<Person> or case (is List<Person>),
filtering exceptions based on type arguments, for example, catch (NotFoundException<Person> pnfe),
testing the runtime value of an instance against a type parameter, for example x is Key, or against a type with a type parameter as an argument, for example, objectList is List<Element>,
obtaining a Type object representing a type with type arguments, for example, List<Person>,
obtaining a Type object representing the runtime value of a type parameter, for example, Element, or of a type with a type parameter as an argument, for example, List<Element>,
obtaining a Type object representing the runtime value of a type argument of an instance using reflection, for example, objectList.type.arguments.first, and
instantiating a type parameter with an initialization parameter specification, for example, Result(parent).

section.para: Sequenced type parameters are not reified. None of the above operations can be performed with a sequenced type parameter.

section.title: Type argument inference
section.para: When a direct invocation expression for a generic method or a direct instantiation expression for a generic class does not explicitly specify type arguments, the type arguments are inferred from the argument expression types. The types of the argument expressions and the declared types of the corresponding parameters determine an inferred lower bound for each type parameter.

If a list of argument expressions has types A1,A2,... and the corresponding list of parameters has declared types P1,P2,..., the inferred lower bound for a type parameter T of the generic declaration is the conjunction of:

listitem.para: the lower bound X explicitly declared by a type constraint on T of form given T abstracts X, if any, with
all inferred lower bounds Ai on Pi for T.

section.para: Given types A and P, we determine the inferred lower bound A on P for T according to the nature of A and P:

listitem.para: If P is exactly T, the inferred lower bound A on P for T is T abstracts A.
If P is a union type Q|R, the lower bound A on P for T is the disjunction of the lower bound A on Q for T with the lower bound A on R for T.
If P is an intersection type Q&R, the lower bound A on P for T is the conjunction of the lower bound A on Q for T with the lower bound A on R for T.
If A is a union type B|C, the lower bound A on P for T is the conjunction of the lower bound B on P for T with the lower bound C on P for T.
If A is an intersection type B&C, the lower bound A on P for T is the disjunction of the lower bound B on P for T with the lower bound C on P for T.
If P is a produced type Q<P1,P2,...> of a parameterized type Q, and A is a subtype of a produced type Q<A1,A2,..>, the lower bound A on P for T is the conjunction of all lower bounds Ai on Pi for T.
Otherwise, if A is not a union or intersection, and if P is neither a produced type, a union, or an intersection, nor exactly T, the lower bound A on P for T is null.

section.para: Where:

listitem.para: the conjunction a lower bound T abstracts A with a lower bound T abstracts B is the lower bound T abstracts A|B,
the disjunction a lower bound T abstracts A with a lower bound T abstracts B is the lower bound T abstracts A&B,
the conjunction or disjunction of a lower bound T abstracts A with a null lower bound is T abstracts A, and
the conjunction or disjunction of two null lower bounds is null.

comment.para: TODO: This does not do justice the the compiler's handling of type parameters which have upper bounds involving other type parameters. In fact, the compiler is also able to infer a type for the type parameter that appears in the upper bound.

section.para: The inferred type argument to a type parameter T of the generic declaration is:

listitem.para: Bottom, if the inferred lower bound for T is null, or, otherwise,
the type A, where the inferred lower bound for T is T abstracts A.

section.para: If the inferred type argument does not satisfy the generic type constraints on T, a compilation error results.
Consider the following invocation:
section.programlisting: Element[] prepend<Element>(Element head, Element[] sequence) { ... } value result = prepend(null, {"hello", "world"});
section.para: The inferred type of Element is the union type String?.
Now consider:
The inferred type of ExtraElement is the union type Integer|Float|String.

comment.para: TODO: What about lower bounds in which the type parameter itself appears (the infamous self-type problem with Comparable and Numeric) or in which another type parameter appears?

TODO: This algorithm works fine for type parameters that appear covariantly in the parameter types, and even okay for type parameters that appear nonvariantly. It doesn't really work very well for type parameters that appear contravariantly, where the constraints are really of form A satisfies T, and they should be combined using intersection, not union, and where the default should be Object not Bottom. Unfortunately we don't currently support intersection types in the spec, or have the machinery to reason about them in the compiler.

Note also that there is something a bit conceptually funny about a type parameter that appears covariantly in a parameter type, and contravariantly in the return type (or vice-versa), so we probably don't really need to bother about the case where a type parameter appears both covariantly and contravariantly.

section.title: Parameters
section.para: A method or class declaration may declare a list or parameters, including, optionally:

listitem.para: one or more defaulted parameters (parameters with default values), and/or
a sequenced parameter (a "vararg" parameter).

section.para: In a parameter list, parameters with default values must occur after required parameters. The sequenced parameter, if any, must occur last.
section.programlisting: Params: "(" Param ("," Param)* ("," DefaultParam)* ("," SequencedParam)? | DefaultParam ("," DefaultParam)* ("," SequencedParam)? | SequencedParam? ")"
section.para: Each parameter is either:

listitem.para: declared with an explicit type and name and may have annotations and/or parameters of its own, or
a named reference to a forward-declared simple attribute, local, or method that directly occurs in the body that immediately follows the parameter list.

section.para: In the case of a reference, the name of the parameter must be the name of a forward-declared simple attribute, local, or method of the method or class it parameterizes, and the type of the parameter is the type of this simple attribute or local, or the callable type of the method. Any argument to the parameter is used as the specification of the value of the attribute or local to which it refers, or as the implementation of the method to which it refers.

section.title: Callable parameters
section.para: A parameter with its own parameter list (or lists) is called a callable parameter.
Think of this as an abstract local method that must be defined by the caller when the method is invoked or the class is instantiated.
A callable parameter declaration is equivalent to a parameter declaration with no parameter lists where the type is the callable type of the method declaration. So the above are equivalent to:

section.title: Defaulted parameters
section.para: Defaulted parameters specify a default argument.
The = specifier is used throughout the language to indicate a value which cannot be reassigned.
Defaulted parameters must occur after non-defaulted parameters in the parameter list.
The type of the default argument expression must be assignable to the declared type of the parameter.
A parameter of a method or class annotated actual may not specify a default argument.
A parameter of a method or class annotated actual inherits the default argument, if any, if the corresponding parameter of the method it refines.

section.title: Sequenced and tuple parameters
section.para: The elipsis ... indicates that a parameter is either:

listitem.para: A sequenced parameter, which accepts a list of arguments of the specified type T, or a single argument of type Iterable<T>. Inside the method or class, the sequenced parameter has type Iterable<T>.

A tuple parameter representing a list of parameters whose types are defined by a sequenced type parameter. Inside the method or class, the argument has the pseudo-type of the sequenced type parameter and is assignable to any tuple parameter of the same pseudo-type.

section.para: The sequenced parameter or tuple parameter must be the last parameter in the list.

comment.para: TODO: what is the syntax for sequenced parameters when declared by reference?

section.title: Destructuring for parameters of type Entry
section.para: A parameter of type Entry may be specified in destructured form.

A destructured parameter declaration of form U u -> V v results in a method with a single parameter of type Entry<U,V>, whose key and item attributes are assigned to u and v within the body of the method. If the method is invoked using a named argument list, it is considered to have two separate parameters u and v.

section.title: Program element annotations
section.para: Declarations may be preceded by a list of annotations. An annotation is an initial lowercase identifier, optionally followed by an argument list. A list of annotations does not require punctuation between the individual annotations in the list.
For an annotation with no arguments, or with only literal-valued positional arguments, the parentheses around, and commas between, the positional arguments may be omitted.
section.programlisting: doc "The user login action" by "Gavin King" "Andrew Haley" throws (DatabaseException -> "if database access fails") seeAlso (LogoutAction.logout) scope (session) action { description="Log In"; url="/login"; } shared deprecated
section.para: An annotation is an invocation of a toplevel method that occurs when the program element is loaded by the virtual machine. The return type of this toplevel method is called the annotation type of the annotation. Invocation of the toplevel method is called evaluation of the annotation. The toplevel method may not declare type parameters.
section.programlisting: shared Scope scope(Scope s) { return s; }
shared Todo todo(String text) { return Todo(text); }

section.title: Annotation arguments
section.para: An annotation may be specified at a program element using any one of three forms.

listitem.para: Using a positional argument invocation of the method:
Using a named argument invocation of the method:
Or using the special abbreviated form for annotations with literal value arguments:

section.title: Annotation types
section.para: The annotation type of an annotation must be a subtype of the interface ConstrainedAnnotation defined in the package ceylon.language.metamodel. Any type which is a subtype of ConstrainedAnnotation is called an annotation type.
The type arguments of this interface express constraints upon how annotations which return the annotation type occur.
There are only two direct subtypes of ConstrainedAnnotation:
section.programlisting: shared interface OptionalAnnotation<out Value, in ProgramElement> satisfies ConstrainedAnnotation<Value,Value?,ProgramElement> given Value satisfies Annotation<Value> given ProgramElement satisfies Annotated {}

shared interface SequencedAnnotation<out T, in ProgramElement> satisfies ConstrainedAnnotation<Value,Value[],ProgramElement> given Value satisfies Annotation<Value> given ProgramElement satisfies Annotated {}
section.para: If A is an annotation type then:

listitem.para: If A is a subtype of OptionalAnnotation, at most one annotation of annotation type A may occur at a given program element.
If A is a subtype of SequencedAnnotation, multiple annotations of annotation type A may occur at a given program element.

If A is a subtype of OptionalAnnotation<A,P>, or SequencedAnnotation<A,P> then an annotation of annotation type A may not occur at a program element whose metamodel expression type is not assignable to P.

section.para: It is perfectly acceptable for multiple toplevel methods to return the same annotation type.

comment.para: TODO: should we let an annotation return multiple instances of an annotation type (A[] where A is an annotation type).

section.title: Annotation values
section.para: An annotation value is the value returned when an annotation is evaluated. We may obtain the annotation values of all annotations of a given annotation type that occur at a given program element by passing the annotation type and program element metamodel reference to the method annotations() defined in the package ceylon.language.metamodel.
